title: How to Make Biscuits and Gravy

methods.name:
Traditional Buttermilk Biscuits[1]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius).
steps.description: Meanwhile, prepare a clean counter or other flat surface by sprinkling it lightly with flour. Line a baking sheet with silicone slip mats or parchment paper.

steps.headline: Whisk together the flour, sugar, and salt.
steps.description: Thoroughly combine these dry ingredients in a medium bowl using a whisk or fork. Do not pack the ingredients down as you mix. For best results, spoon the flour into your measuring cup and level it off with the back of a kitchen knife. Avoid scooping the flour directly into the cup, since doing so will pack the flour down and cause you to gather too much flour.

steps.headline: Cut in the shortening and butter.
steps.description: Use a pastry blender to cut the two ingredients into the flour mixture until coarse crumbs form. If you do not have a pastry blender, you can use a butter knife. Cut the shortening and butter with the knife, tossing the pieces about in the flour mixture as you work. Work quickly so that the butter does not melt.

steps.headline: Add the buttermilk.
steps.description: Use your hands or the back of a spoon to form a well in the flour mixture. Slowly pour the buttermilk into the well all at once. Stir with a spoon to combine. Only stir long enough to moisten the dough. It should be neither sticky nor dry; instead, it should be fairly tacky. If the dough seems too dry, add 1 to 2 Tbsp (15 to 30 ml) of additional buttermilk to moisten it.

steps.headline: Turn the dough out onto your floured counter.
steps.description: Gently fold the dough over itself two or three times using your hands. Shape into a rough piece roughly 3/4-inch (2-cm) thick. Lightly flour your hands before handling the dough to prevent it from sticking to your skin. If you decide to use a rolling pin, lightly flour the rolling pin before bringing it into contact with the dough.

steps.headline: Cut the dough into rounds.
steps.description: Use a 2-inch (5-cm) round biscuit cutter, dipped in flour, to cup the dough into rounds. Arrange these rounds on your prepared baking sheet, placing them 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5 cm) apart. You could use the rim of a glass in the absence of a biscuit cutter or cookie cutter. Dip the biscuit cutter in flour in between cuttings to prevent the dough from sticking. Press straight down with the biscuit cutter. Do not twist the cutter as you form the biscuits. Leaving space in between the biscuits will give them crunchy sides. For soft sides, place them together so that they just barely touch.

steps.headline: Bake for 15 to 18 minutes in your preheated oven.
steps.description: The biscuits should be golden brown on top when finished. You may need to turn the baking sheet around halfway through the baking time to ensure even browning.

steps.headline: Serve warm with gravy.
steps.description: Transfer the biscuits to your intended serving dishes and ladle them with traditional sausage gravy before serving.

methods.name:
Traditional Sausage Gravy[2]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Brown the sausage in a skillet.
steps.description: Crumble and cook the sausage in a large, heavy skillet over medium-high heat. Stir the sausage as it browns to prevent it from burning. Do not drain the sausage once brown.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the sausage with flour, garlic powder, onion power, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Evenly sprinkle these dry ingredients over the sausage and stir. Cook for another 2 to 4 minutes. Make sure to coat the sausage evenly with the dry ingredients. Stir the contents of the skillet constantly to prevent the flour or sausage from burning. The flour should be browned before you proceed to the next step. Browning the flour is important. If you skip this step, your gravy will taste like raw flour.

steps.headline: Mix in the milk.
steps.description: Pour the milk into skillet in once batch. Stir the milk into the meat mixture to incorporate it thoroughly.

steps.headline: Let simmer until thickened.
steps.description: Drop the heat to medium and let the gravy reach a low simmer. Allow it to continue cooking until it reaches your desired level of thickness. For a thin gravy, remove it from the heat as soon as it begins to thicken. For a relatively thick gravy, allow it to simmer for 10 minutes or so on low heat.

steps.headline: Serve with traditional buttermilk biscuits.
steps.description: Pour generously over your traditional biscuits and serve while still hot.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius).
steps.description: Meanwhile, prepare a baking sheet by lining it with parchment paper or nonstick aluminum foil.

steps.headline: Combine the baking mix and water.
steps.description: Mix the baking mix and water together in a medium mixing bowl until the dough forms a ball. You can use your hands to mix the ingredients or you can use a wooden or plastic mixing spoon. If you use your hands, make sure to wash and dry them thoroughly before you touch the dough.

steps.headline: Drop the biscuits onto your prepared baking sheet.
steps.description: Use 1 Tbsp (15 ml) of dough per biscuit. Place the biscuits 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5 cm) apart from one another to give them space to expand as they bake.

steps.headline: Bake for 10 to 12 minutes.
steps.description: Cook the biscuits in your preheated oven until they turn golden-brown. Remove from the oven when done and let them cool to the touch before handling.

steps.headline: Arrange finished biscuits on a platter.
steps.description: You can place the finished biscuits on a large serving platter or on individual serving dishes. Serve the biscuits with warm shortcut gravy.

steps.headline: Combine the three ingredients in a medium saucepan.
steps.description: Pour the water and oil into the saucepan. Whisk the gravy mix into the liquid until smooth. If you have sausage, bacon, or beef drippings on hand, use those instead of vegetable oil. A sausage-flavored country gravy mix or country gravy mix will lend the most traditional flavor, but you could also use a brown gravy mix or poultry gravy mix. The amount of gravy mix called for in this recipe usually equals two packets.

steps.headline: Bring to a boil.
steps.description: Bring the gravy mixture to a boil over medium heat. Stir or whisk the gravy frequently as it cooks.

steps.headline: Let simmer until thickened.
steps.description: Reduce the heat to low as soon as the gravy begins to boil. Let it simmer for an additional minute, stirring occasionally to prevent it from burning. The gravy is ready once it thickens up. Adjust the cooking time as needed. Note that the gravy will continue to thicken as it stands.

steps.headline: Ladle over finished biscuits.
steps.description: Remove the gravy from the heat once thickened and ladle it generously over your shortcut biscuits.

steps.headline: Heat the oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (180 degrees Celsius).
steps.description: Prepare a baking sheet by lining it with parchment paper or nonstick aluminum foil. Note that the instructions for your refrigerated biscuit dough may vary from those provided here. These instructions are meant to serve as a general guideline. When preparing your biscuits, follow the baking instructions provided on the label.

steps.headline: Arrange the biscuits on your baking sheet.
steps.description: The biscuits should be arranged on your prepared baking sheet roughly 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5 cm) apart from one another. If you place the biscuits any closer, they may stick together as they expand in the oven.

steps.headline: Bake the biscuits in in your preheated oven.
steps.description: Let the biscuits cook for 11 to 17 minutes, or until they turn golden brown.

steps.headline: Meanwhile, pour your can of gravy into a small saucepan.
steps.description: Premade commercial gravies are already completely cooked. All you need to do to prepare the gravy is warm it up. If possible, use a "country style sausage gravy." If this type of premade gravy is not available at your store, however, you could also use a premade brown gravy or chicken gravy.

steps.headline: Heat the gravy on medium-low.
steps.description: Warm the gravy on the stove using medium-low heat until bubbles start to form, indicating that the gravy is heated through. This should only take a few minutes. Stir the gravy frequently as it heats up to prevent it from burning.

steps.headline: Pour the warm gravy over the finished biscuits.
steps.description: Place one or two biscuits on a serving dish and ladle over the warm gravy. Allow the gravy to soak into the biscuit slightly before enjoying.

Note that the instructions for your refrigerated biscuit dough may vary from those provided here. These instructions are meant to serve as a general guideline. All you need to do to prepare the gravy is warm it up. If possible, use a "country style sausage gravy." Allow the gravy to soak into the biscuit slightly before enjoying.
